topic.title: Timestamp Counter

body.p: The timestamp counter is a free running counter based on the system reference clock. The counter output is used to provide the timestamps that may be inserted in the packet by the packet assembler. The counter output is also available to the test packet monitor where it can be compared to the timestamp that was inserted into the packet by an upstream packet assembler to determine the total path latency.

If the upstream packet assembler is in another device, then the timestamp counters must be synchronized across the devices to provide a meaningful comparison. The timestamp counter can synchronize to the device frame pulse input, the PMON synchronization input, or the time-of-day one pulse-per-second input or output signals. The timestamp counter can select one of these device signals to align the counter roll-over to. When the selected signal has a rising edge, if the counter is not within a tolerance window of rolling over, it is reset to 0. Interrupt bits are provided to indicate whenever the selected counter synchronization source has had an event, and whenever the counter re-synchronizes to the source.

The timestamp counter, packet generator timestamp insertion, and packet monitor latency calculator use a 32-bit field for the timestamp. The roll-over value for the timestamp counter and latency calculator is programmable. The timestamp counter can be programmed to the same period as the synchronization source input to prevent undesired repeated re-synchronizations. Alternatively, the timestamp counter can be configured to synchronize once to the selected input source and then free-run.
